    Amyloid-Binding Alcohol Dehydrogenase (ABAD) Inhibitors for the Treatment of Alzheimer’s Disease

    Miniperspective

    • Ahmed Morsy
      Ahmed Morsy
      Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, School of Pharmacy, Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, Amarillo, Texas 79106, United States
      More by Ahmed Morsy
      View Biography
      •  and 
    • Paul C. Trippier*
      Paul C. Trippier
      Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, School of Pharmacy, Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, Amarillo, Texas 79106, United States
      Center for Chemical Biology, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas 79409, United States
      *E-mail: [email protected]. Phone: +1-806-414-9245.
      More by Paul C. Trippier
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-4947-5782
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2019, 62, 9, 4252–4264
    Publication Date (Web):November 16, 2018

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common dementia. No cure exists, and current treatment only manages early symptoms. Mitochondrial dysfunction is a hallmark of amyloid-β (Aβ) neurotoxicity, the pathogenic protein implicated in AD. This is due in part to the interaction between Aβ and amyloid-binding alcohol dehydrogenase (ABAD). This mitochondrial protein is a vital energy regulator that, following Aβ binding, activates signaling cascades that lead to neuronal death. One of the most significant roles of ABAD is to maintain the balance of estradiol/estrone in neurons. However, the Aβ–ABAD interaction disrupts this balance and leads to a reduction in levels of estradiol, thus leading to an increase in reactive oxygen species levels and to apoptosis. Two additional proteins, peroxiredoxin-2 and endophilin-1, are implicated in Aβ–ABAD complex-mediated toxicity. Targeting the Aβ–ABAD interaction has emerged as a novel therapeutic strategy for AD. Herein, we review the chemistry and pharmacology of reported ABAD inhibitors.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia affecting millions of people worldwide. Clinically, AD is characterized by loss of cognitive function including memory, language, and motor skills.(1) The main pathological hallmarks of the AD brain are the presence of extracellular senile plaques of amyloid-β (Aβ) peptides, neurofibrillary tangles and loss of neuronal cells, particularly cholinergic neurons.(2,3) The leading molecular theory of the early stages of AD is the amyloid cascade hypothesis;(4) an imbalance in the production or clearance of the Aβ peptide results in accumulation of Aβ and initiation of a cascade of events that lead to neurodegeneration and dementia.(5) However, the druggability of the amyloid cascade hypothesis is in doubt following several phase III clinical trial failures of beta-site amyloid precursor protein cleaving enzyme (BACE) inhibitors and antibodies.(6,7) Amyloid then aggregates to form oligomers that are neurotoxic.(8,9) The oligomers accumulate in the mitochondria of neurons leading to a series of slow and separate mechanistic neurodegenerative events that eventually lead to neurotoxicity and synaptic dysfunction.(10) This accumulation also leads, through an as yet unknown process, to the formation of hyperphosphorylated tau protein, part of an overall neurodegenerative mechanism that is deemed to be toxic to neurons and leads to neuroinflammation. Loss of synaptic function and mitochondrial abnormalities are associated with early stages of AD which directly relate to the process of toxicity caused by amyloid and contribute to the neurodegeneration which ultimately leads to brain atrophy and patient death.(11−13)
    Currently, there are no disease-modifying therapies for the treatment of AD.(14) Only five drugs (Figure 1) have been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), four of which are cholinesterase inhibitors (tacrine,(15) donepezil,(16) rivastigmine,(17) and galantamine(18)) and one of which is a N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist (memantine(19)). These pharmacological agents have had limited effect in improving the cognitive function of AD patients and do not slow the progression of the disease. Clinical studies have shown that these agents temporarily stabilize cognitive impairment and help to maintain global function, delaying the need for patient palliative care by only a few months.(18,20,21) Clearly, the development of novel treatment options capable of modifying the underlying pathophysiology of AD is an unmet clinical need that results in significant morbidity and mortality.
    Treating AD has proven highly challenging with all completed clinical trials failing to achieve a positive clinical effect, highlighting that a clear understanding of AD pathology is still unclear. A relatively large number of chemically diverse secretase inhibitors (both β and γ) that target the formation of Aβ have failed clinical trials, showing no benefit in slowing the progression of the disease. Kumar et al. recently summarized the use of secretase inhibitors, γ-secretase modulators, and α-secretase enhancers in clinical trials, and the reader is directed to this review and included references for more in depth analysis.(22) Trials of agents that work to target the clearance of Aβ have also failed. Antibodies that bind Aβ and reduce its accumulation in the brain or initiate an immune response have proven unsuccessful in offering an effective treatment, with several high profile clinical trial failures.(23,24) Panzaa et al. highlighted the use of amyloid-based immunotherapy for Alzheimer’s disease as still questionable.(25) Hence, the ongoing clinical trials using amyloid-based immunotherapy (ClinicalTrials.gov identifiers NCT01127633, NCT01900665, NCT01760005) are cast into doubt. Perhaps the continuing failures of these clinical trials targeting Aβ are due to approaching protein aggregation at too late a stage of disease progression. The accumulation of Aβ has been shown to begin in the brain before signs of cognitive decline become apparent.(26−28) Since Aβ is formed intracellularly,(29) accumulating evidence suggests that early Aβ toxicity may be initiated from its binding to intracellular targets resulting in disruption of cellular biochemistry that leads to cell death. The identification and pharmacological modulation of cellular targets that bind Aβ may enable therapeutic intervention at earlier stages of AD progression, with the caveat that biomarkers for early stage AD are currently lacking and are urgently needed.(30,31) Due to the role of mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress in the early pathology of AD, mitochondrial targets have promising potenial.(32−35)
    Genetics have a role to play within AD; patients with a mutation in amyloid precursor protein (APP), which results in overproduction of Aβ, will experience early onset AD.(36) Patients with a mutation in apolipoprotein E4 (APOE4), which affects the clearance of Aβ, will experience late onset AD.(37) In addition, several other gene mutations have been discovered such as presenilin-1 and presenilin-2 mutations, which increase the risk for developing AD.(38) However, the majority of AD patients have no known genetic mutation, thus supporting the amyloid cascade hypothesis as the underlying pathophysiology resulting in disease onset.

    Mitochondrial Dysfunction in Alzheimer’s Disease

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The amyloid cascade hypothesis has gained traction over the past decades and is now the most widely accepted theory as to the cause of AD.(39−41) Recent studies indicate that the soluble oligomeric form of Aβ is the most toxic species of amyloid and correlates well with the severity of the disease.(9,42) Alzheimer’s disease pathology is believed to start 15–20 years before manifestation of symptoms, which presents a general hypothesis of a slow neurodegenerative mechanism caused by amyloid aggregation. The exact mechanism of amyloid toxicity remains unknown despite extensive research in the past several decades. Numerous studies indicate the presence of amyloid protein intracellularly which led to the modification of the original amyloid cascade hypothesis to identify the intracellular oligomers as the neurotoxic form of Aβ.(43,44) The formation of Aβ starts by a transmembrane protein, APP (695–770 amino acids in length), which is sequentially cleaved by the aspartate proteases β- and γ-secretase, that leads to the formation of Aβ peptide (1–42) and a degenerated C-terminus. Amyloid then aggregates to form dimers, tetramers, and oligomers.(45−47) Extracellularly, Aβ can have different molecular conformations, from dimers, tetramers, and oligomers, forming highly aggregated fibers that are the major component of amyloid plaques.(48,49) The presence of Aβ intracellularly causes toxicity through different mechanisms. Mitochondrial dysfunction is the hallmark of Aβ-induced toxicity.(50−52) The presence of Aβ in the mitochondria is implicated in the free radical generation and resultant oxidative damage seen in AD.(10) Decrease in glucose utilization in neurons of AD patients further suggests mitochondrial defects. Recent studies revealed that cognitively normal patients with the APOE4 allele have abnormal glucose metabolism, suggesting that mitochondrial dysfunction is an early stage of AD progression.(53,54) Further, in in vitro assays testing for Krebs cycle enzymes using cells obtained from the autopsy of AD patient brains, mitochondrial enzymes have been shown to be significantly decreased, including critical enzymes in the mitochondrial respiratory chain; pyruvate dehydrogenase, ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and isocitrate dehydrogenase.(55) Several studies have shown that Aβ toxicity in neurons could directly damage mitochondrial respiration and associated enzyme activity.(56,57) Accumulation of Aβ has also been associated with a decrease in the activity of cytochrome c oxidase, the terminal enzyme in the electron transport chain. These findings suggest the involvement of mitochondria in Aβ toxicity and impairment of glucose metabolism due to dysfunction of mitochondrial respiratory function. Therefore, mitochondrial proteins have gained much attention as possible mechanisms by which Aβ causes its toxicity, leading in turn to suggest these enzymes as possible pharmacological targets for the treatment of AD.
    Mitochondrial dysfunction is associated with synaptic dysfunction in the early pathological features of AD.(12) Binding of Aβ to proteins in the mitochondria results in synaptic dysfunction, impaired mitochondrial respiration, ATP depletion, and production of reactive oxygen species (ROS).(58) Multiple reports have studied the effect of incubating Aβ with isolated mitochondria which resulted in reduction of mitochondrial complex IV activity, as well as the formation of the mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) which leads to apoptosis.(59,60) Two mitochondrial targets in particular have become the center of interest; amyloid binding alcohol dehydrogenase (ABAD) and cyclophilin D (CypD). The two proteins have been heavily implicated in mitochondrial toxicity. Binding of Aβ, in its oligomeric form, to ABAD has been shown to inhibit enzyme activity in the micromolar range.(45,61) Due to its essential physiological role in the mitochondria, human ABAD acts as a cofactor to Aβ-induced cellular stress.(58) Several other mitochondrial targets of Aβ are being investigated beyond ABAD, and for further information on this emerging area the reader is directed to excellent reviews on the subject.(62,63)

    Amyloid Binding Alcohol Dehydrogenase

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    First identified by a yeast two-hybrid screen for Aβ binding molecules,(64) ABAD is also known as 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 10 (17β-HSD10), endoplasmic reticulum-associated amyloid β-peptide-binding protein (ERAB), and short-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase (SCHAD). The enzyme is a homotetramer protein complex with a molecular mass of 108 kDa, consisting of 261 amino acids, that is encoded by the gene HSD17B10 located at chromosome Xp11.2.(65) Binding of Aβ to ABAD has been implicated in the development of AD; recent studies detected elevated ABAD levels in the regions of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex which are generally affected by AD pathology.(64,66−68) Binding of Aβ was found to be to nanomolar affinity (40–70 nM),(45) but it is not until the micromolar ranges where ABAD activity is compromised.(45,61,66) This suggests that a higher concentration of Aβ, likely in its oligomeric form, is required to occupy the binding site and induce the observed conformation changes in the enzyme.
    The mitochondrial enzyme ABAD is a multifunctional protein, fulfilling several metabolic roles. The enzyme plays a role in the β-oxidation cycle, oxidizing 3-hydroxyacyl-CoAs.(69) The enzyme functions as a vital energy regulator within the mitochondria, containing a Rossman fold that acts to oxidize alcohols and reduce aldehydes and ketones on a variety of substrates with a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) molecule as a cofactor.(70,71) The enzyme is also required for the catabolism of isoleucine, in which it catalyzes the conversion of 2-methyl-3-hydroxybutyryl-CoA (MHB) to 2-methylacetoacetyl-CoA.(72) Wide substrate specificity exists including steroids, simple alcohols, fatty acid metabolites, and amino acid metabolites.(73,74) The enzyme catalyzes the third step of mitochondrial oxidation, converting l-3-hydroxyacyl-CoA in the presence of NAD+ to 3-ketoacyl-CoA, NADH, and H+. The enzyme has a role in sex steroid and neurosteroid metabolism due to its 3α- and 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase activity.(75,76) The oxidation of 3α-adiol to 5α-dihydrotestosterone in androgen metabolism is catalyzed by ABAD, and it converts 17β-estradiol to estrone in estrogen metabolism. A broad range of substrates can be controlled by ABAD,(73) although recent studies reveal a greater specificity for neurosteroids. It was recently determined that ABAD activity in neurosteroid metabolism of estrogens is a unidirectional process breaking down estradiol to estrone.(77)
    Several essential functions in the brain are controlled by ABAD. Reports indicate that ABAD is one of the protein constituents of postsynaptic density, a complex of proteins that maintains the integrity and structures of the synapse and also mediates responses from the presynaptic axon terminals.(78,79) Moreover, function of ABAD has also been associated with GABAA receptors, as it catalyzes the oxidation of the neurosteroids allopregnanolone and allotetrahydrodeoxycorticosterone, both of which are positive modulators of GABAA receptors in the brain.(80,81) After oxidation, these substrates increase receptor opening frequency and duration.(82)
    The protective effects of ABAD have been shown in cases of ischemia and Parkinson’s disease.(83,84) Overexpression of ABAD in neuroblastoma cells, however, enhances the cytotoxic effects of Aβ.(58) The enzyme’s activity in the wild type form, but not the mutant form, has been linked to mitochondrial and oxidative stress in vitro(64,66) and in vivo.(58,66) Binding of Aβ to ABAD has been shown to cause disruption in enzyme activity toward specific substrates. Such substrates are known to possess neuroprotective effects in processes directly related to AD pathology. For example, estradiol can reduce the generation of Aβ by altering the metabolism of APP and disrupting its trafficking.(85−87) Moreover, estradiol has been shown to inhibit tau hyperphosphorylation and can also modulate glycogen synthase kinase-3β (GSK-3β) activity, a kinase that is involved in tau phosphorylation. Estradiol deactivates GSK-3β by inducing its phosphorylation, thereafter reducing tau phosphorylation.(88−90)
    The presence of Aβ in the mitochondria triggers a cascade of events that leads to apoptosis.(65) In vitro binding studies determined Aβ (1–20), Aβ (1–40), and Aβ (1–42) to be toxic in a dose-dependent manner when bound to ABAD. However, Aβ (25–35) showed no binding to ABAD, indicating that only specific forms of Aβ bind to a specific site within ABAD, forming a complex in the mitochondrial matrix.(65) Methylene blue, an FDA approved drug used to treat methemoglobinemia and cyanide poisoning, became a drug of interest for the treatment of AD. The molecule is currently in phase III clinical trials under the name of Rember (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03539380) to assess its effect in improving cognitive function. Preliminary trials resulted in an 81% decrease in the rate of mental decline compared to patients taking placebo.(91,92) In mechanistic studies, it was proposed that methylene blue inhibits the Aβ–ABAD interaction and decreases mitochondrial dysfunction by decreasing the expression of ABAD levels, in addition to decreasing Aβ levels.(93)
    The Aβ–ABAD complex has been studied extensively using different techniques. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) showed dose-dependent binding of ABAD to Aβ.(94) Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) studies revealed that Aβ binding to ABAD induces conformational changes in the enzyme structure, thereby inactivating normal enzymatic turnover and ultimately resulting in neuronal apoptosis.(66,95,96) X-ray crystal structure studies of the Aβ–ABAD complex revealed that protein–protein interaction has a direct link to Aβ toxicity.(66) Coimmunoprecipitation followed by immunoblotting analysis detected Aβ–ABAD complex in the AD brain.(64,97) Crystal structures of the interaction of ABAD with its substrates (fatty acids and hydroxysteroids) support the proposed physiological and pathological relevance to AD progression.(70) Confocal microscopy studies were also performed to confirm the mitochondrial colocalization and interaction of ABAD with Aβ in both AD patients and transgenic mice overexpressing ABAD and mutant APP (Tg mAPP/ABAD).(66) Neurons from these animals exhibited increased oxidative stress, increased generation of ROS, DNA fragmentation, neuronal apoptosis, and impairment in learning compared to single-transgenic mAPP mice.(66) In another study, neurons from Tg mAPP/ABAD mice were shown to exhibit decreased activity of cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme, spontaneous release of ROS, loss of mitochondrial membrane potential, a decrease in ATP production, and release of cytochrome c from mitochondria with subsequent induction of caspase-3-like activity followed by apoptotic cell death.(58) These findings overwhelmingly confirmed the Aβ–ABAD interaction as crucial to elicit Aβ toxicity and that the binding causes a cascade of events that eventually lead to neuronal damage. Thereafter, studies focused on identifying inhibitors for this interaction in order to further study the enzyme and to potentially improve cognitive health. The search for inhibitors started with a decoy peptide, synthesized to encompass the LD loop, the region in the enzyme that is crucial for Aβ binding. By use of SPR, the peptide was shown to prevent binding of Aβ, confirming the LD loop of the enzyme to be an ideal target for molecular modeling to identify small molecules that can inhibit the interaction.(66) Moreover, in vivo inhibition of the Aβ–ABAD interaction using the decoy peptide reduces Aβ accumulation and improves mitochondrial function in a mouse model of AD.(98)

    Aβ–ABAD Toxicity

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The mechanism by which the Aβ–ABAD complex elicits, or potentiates, toxicity is still unclear. However, it is well established that Aβ binding to ABAD induces a conformational change in the enzyme that prevents the binding of NAD+, preventing the enzyme performing its role in the oxidation of substrates, leading to changes in mitochondrial membrane permeability, which in turn has deleterious effects on mitochondrial enzymes.(66) Another consideration is that formation of the protein–protein interaction prevents ABAD from carrying out its function to remove toxic aldehydes.(99) The enzyme functions as a modulator for several different substrates that have been implicated in Aβ–ABAD complex toxicity resulting in a cascade of toxic events that follow Aβ–ABAD binding (Figure 2).(100−102)
    Physiological levels of estradiol in the mitochondria play a vital role as both antioxidants and as calcium regulators and as such are an essential determinant of neuronal survival.(86) Higher prevalence and incidence of AD are encountered in women, with two-thirds of AD patients being female.(103) Studies show that women exhibit greater senile plaque deposition than men.(104) Estradiol binds to the nuclear estrogen receptors α and β and acts as a transcription factor. It enhances the expression of antiapoptotic proteins, such as Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL, and downregulates the expression of Bim, a proapoptotic factor, preventing programmed cell death.(90,100) Estradiol also activates antioxidant systems to protect neuronal cells from apoptosis by upregulating the expression of manganese superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase.(101) In a study employing ovariectomized female rats, estradiol showed direct effects as an antioxidant and subsequently decreased oxidative DNA damage in the mitochondria.(105) One of the most significant roles of ABAD is to maintain the balance of estradiol/estrone in neurons. However, Aβ–ABAD interaction disrupts this balance and leads to a reduction in levels of estradiol, thus leading to an increase in ROS levels, DNA fragmentation, and apoptosis.(86)
    Two other ABAD-related proteins have been identified to date that are elevated subsequent to Aβ–ABAD interaction. The first, peroxiredoxin-2 (Prdx-2), functions as an antioxidant and has been shown to be inactivated in AD.(106) In transgenic AD mice and the post-mortem human brain of AD patients, the expression of Prdx-2 is shown to be elevated due to the attempted protection of neurons from Aβ-induced toxicity.(106) Inactivation of Prdx-2 is controlled by a kinase that has been shown to be elevated in AD, CDK5,(107,108) which phosphorylates Thr(89) and results in deactivation of Prdx-2.(109)
    The second ABAD-related protein, endophilin-1 (Ep-1), is a member of a family of proteins that are responsible for synaptic vesicle endocytosis, mitochondrial function, and receptor trafficking.(110) This family of proteins has been implicated in a number of neurodegenerative diseases,(111) including in AD where it is overexpressed.(112) The activity of stress kinase c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) has been shown to be linked to Ep-1 in primary cortical neurons and HEK-293 cells.(112,113) Through a germinal center-like kinase (GLK)-mediated pathway, Ep-1 binds to GLK by its C-terminal domain affecting lipid membrane curvature for synaptic vesicle formation.(111) This results in the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase 1 (MAP3K1),(114) which then activates a cascade of kinases that eventually leads to the translocation of JNK to the nucleus or other target sites to phosphorylate downstream effectors, thereby affecting significant aspects of neuronal function such as neurite outgrowth, mitochondrial function, synaptic plasticity, and apoptosis.(115) These consequences of ABAD-related protein activity highlight a wider role of ABAD in healthy neuronal function. Thus, Aβ binding to ABAD does not just inhibit enzyme activity; it manipulates its activity toward specific substrates and proteins. Production or inhibition of these substrates is implicit in the complex mechanisms of toxicity induced by Aβ–ABAD interaction.

    Imaging

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The development of a labeled or fluorogenic ligand which can be used in brain imaging techniques such as positron emission tomography (PET), single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT), or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) would provide a useful tool for studying ongoing processes in the brain and may assist in the identification of biomarkers to monitor AD progression.(116) Cyclohexenylaminonaphthalene alcohol (CHANA) (Scheme 1) is a fluorogenic probe developed for imaging ABAD activity.(117) The probe is structurally similar to estradiol, a known substrate for ABAD, and through fluorescent microscopy the fluorogenic probe enables noninvasive and continuous measurement of ABAD activity in cells. The CHANA probe exhibits very low fluorescence, whereas the corresponding ketone product, cyclohexenylaminonaphthalene ketone (CHANK), is highly fluorescent.(117) This property allows active monitoring of ABAD activity by measuring the intensity of accumulated CHANK. A specific enantiomer of CHANA has been speculated to be a selective substrate for ABAD;(118) (−)–CHANA showed specific binding to ABAD and can be utilized both in in vitro enzyme assays or for fluorescence microscopy studies to evaluate ABAD activity. The probe was used to evaluate the change in enzyme activity following Aβ binding in the living cell and demonstrated that the enzyme activity is reduced following Aβ binding.(118) A variety of benzothiazole chemotypes are being employed for imaging purposes, and for further information regarding their use the reader is directed to an excellent review that discusses the use of benzothiazole scaffold in the CNS.(119)

    Assay Methods

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A number of assay protocols have been developed to test the activity of small molecule ABAD inhibitors. A high-throughput screen (HTS) was developed that employed binding of 5 μg of Aβ to a 2.5 μM concentration of isolated biotin-labeled ABAD, which ultimately identified frentizole, a known bioactive compound, as an Aβ–ABAD interaction inhibitor.(94)
    Estradiol has long been used as an indicator of assay readout results, and kits are commercially available to quantify the amount of estradiol produced by measurement of absorbance at 412 nm. The level of estradiol present in SH-SY5Y cells treated with 0.5 μM concentration of Aβ and incubated with derivatives that function as ABAD inhibitors can therefore be determined as directly proportional to the potency of the inhibitor allowing direct comparison of the small molecules tested.(120) This assay has the advantage of determining the activity of the tested compounds in an intact cell in the presence of Aβ.
    An in vitro assay and HTS platform have been used for identification of small molecules that can modulate ABAD activity in the presence of NADH.(121) The assay tested 6759 compounds for activity to inhibit ABAD, identifying 16 hits. Acetoacetyl-CoA was considered to be the best substrate for ABAD as it provides a balanced chance of finding competitive, noncompetitive, or uncompetitive inhibitors. In the presence of NADH, acetoacetyl-CoA, and isolated ABAD enzyme, the potency of the tested compounds can be determined by the change of NADH absorbance. The concentrations needed to produce a functional signal are 2.5 nM ABAD, 117 μM acetoacetyl-CoA, and 100 μM NADH.(121) This enzyme assay directly tested potency of compounds toward inhibiting enzyme activity in the presence of acetoacetyl-CoA, assessing the reduction activity of the enzyme. This version of the ABAD enzyme assay was used to identify virtually all of the known ABAD inhibitors, with few exceptions.
    An alternative assay employs HEK-293 cells, which only express low levels of steroidogenic enzymes, transfected with the ABAD enzyme and utilizing radiolabeled estradiol at a concentration of 1 μM. The radioactivity associated with the estradiol substrate and its metabolite is quantified to determine the percentage of transformation and thereby the percentage of inhibition.(122) This enzyme assay offers the advantage of testing the steroidal activity of ABAD in the presence of inhibitors while minimizing the effect of any other steroidal enzyme in an intact cell to avoid false positives.
    More recently, two biological assays have been reported that measure the inhibition of steroidal derivative transformation by ABAD. These assays use isolated ABAD enzyme with either radiolabeled allopregnanolone or estradiol as steroidal substrates for ABAD. The assays were optimized to have a fixed concentration of 1 μM for allopregnanolone or estradiol, 400 ng/mL for ABAD, and 1 mM for the NAD+ cofactor. The inhibition activity of tested compounds was measured by quantifying the transformation of radiolabeled allopregnanolone or estradiol to their metabolites after separation using thin layer chromatography plates. This enzyme assay measures the oxidation activity of the enzyme through allopregnanolone and estradiol, substrates normally oxidized by ABAD in the presence of NAD+.(123)

    ABAD Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The search for small molecule inhibitors of the Aβ–ABAD interaction has been challenging. While the decoy peptide mentioned above does inhibit the interaction, peptide-based compounds encounter significant limitations in progressing to a clinical therapeutic.(124)
    Currently, only a limited number of small molecule ABAD inhibitors are known. Fused pyrazole compounds have been extensively studied for their ability to inhibit ABAD.(125) A potent ABAD inhibitor, AG18051 (1), containing a pyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidine-4(1H)-thione backbone (IC50 = 92 nM) has been reported. By use of the evolutionary programming for molecular replacement (EPMR) structure-based drug design program, the inhibitor was identified and cocrystallized with human ABAD in the presence of NAD+ cofactor. Compound 1 is the most potent ABAD inhibitor known to date that has AD-related biological activity in intact cells. The inhibitor occupies the substrate binding pocket and forms a covalent adduct with the NAD+ cofactor within the active site of ABAD (Figure 3).(71) Compound 1 has been used to test the relevance of Aβ–ABAD in AD pathology in vitro.(86) Moreover, it has been shown to ameliorate Aβ-induced toxicity at the cellular level.(71,120)
    Further molecular dynamics studies on 1 highlighted that the relative conformation of the azepane and phenyl rings of 1 appears to be related to the flexibility of the substrate binding loop of ABAD. During simulation of the 1–ABAD complex the substrate binding loop moves to a more open conformation which in turn leads to the weakening, or loss, of hydrophobic interactions with the azepane and phenyl rings of 1. However, due to conformational flux between the azepane and the phenyl rings, these rings may sample many conformations and the phenyl ring tends to reconfigure inside the more spacious binding cavity in order to keep the hydrophobic interactions with the loop, thereby hindering its open conformation. Thus, the conformation of these two rings is of importance to the inhibition of enzyme activity.(96) Further SAR studies on 1 identified six inhibitors with nanomolar ABAD inhibition activity (Table 1).(125) The resulting most potent inhibitor (2) features the addition of a hydroxy group in position 3 of the phenyl ring, which possessed an ABAD IC50 of 51 nM. Other modifications that resulted in nanomolar inhibition activity included substitution of the azepane ring, and compound 3, containing a 4-butylpiperidin-4-ol moiety, possessed an IC50 of 71 nM. Substitution of the azepane heterocycle with 4-phenylpiperidin-4-ol (4) or 4-(4-bromophenyl)piperidin-4-ol (5) resulted in inhibitors with IC50 values of 81 nM and 82 nM, respectively. Rupture of the azepane ring to introduce a diethylamine moiety (6) or ring expansion to an azocane ring (7) resulted in inhibitors with equipotent activity to 1, possessing IC50 values of 93 nM and 96 nM, respectively, indicating that hydrophobicity at this position of the scaffold does not correlate to inhibition activity. These nanomolar analogues have not been tested further in an in vitro setting, and some may be expected to suffer from limiting solubility issues based on work conducted in our laboratory.
    Table 1. Derivatives of AG18051 with Nanomolar ABAD Inhibition Activity
    A computational optimization study was performed to predict analogues of 1 with higher potency.(126) Using molecular mechanics Poisson–Boltzmann surface area methodology, prediction of the relative free energy of differently modified inhibitor–NAD enzyme complexes was calculated. Simple modifications were evaluated with the aim of keeping the overall structure of 1 to preserve favorable absorption distribution metabolism and excretion (ADME) properties.(126) The study identified 15 inhibitors that showed a decrease in binding free energy up to −6.97 kcal/mol. These inhibitors are in the same range of molecular weight and hydrogen bond donor/acceptor count as the parent compound and are not predicted to adversely affect the ADME profile. Substitutions deemed favorable for stronger binding were located on the phenyl and azepane ring moieties. The introduction of a methoxy group to the seven-membered ring in position 1, or a methyl group in position 7 or 9, resulted in predicted formation of a strong hydrogen bond and therefore higher binding affinity. The purine ring, given its importance in adduct formation and consequent enzyme inhibition, was not subjected to chemical modification.

    Steroidal Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Interestingly, during the search for inhibitors of 17β-HSD isoforms for the treatment of estrogen-related diseases,(127) Ayan et al. identified the steroidal compound RM-532-46 (8) as a reversible ABAD inhibitor (IC50 = 0.55 μM).(122) Note that the assay used in this study was to evaluate the inhibitory potency of the steroidal analogues in the transformation of estradiol into estrone by ABAD which was transfected in intact HEK-293 cells. However, most recently further SAR studies on compound 8 and its analogues were performed using the two new developed assays mentioned above (radiolabeled allopregnanolone and estradiol enzyme inhibition assays). Compound 8 at 100 μM showed 14.7% inhibition of ABAD activity in the allopregnanolone assay and at 300 μM showed 30% inhibition of ABAD activity in the estradiol assay. The minor modification of changing the ketone group in position 17 with an α-OH resulted in increased activity with inhibition of 41.7% of ABAD activity in the allopregnanolone assay at 100 μM concentration and a similar inhibition to compound 8 in the estradiol assay at 300 μM concentration. Calculated IC50 for compound 8 was determined in the allopregnanolone assay to be 985 μM and in the estradiol assay to be 710 μM despite possessing IC50 of 0.55 μM in HEK-293 cells transfected by ABAD. This raises an important issue as to the reproducibility of inhibition activity between different assay types and makes the direct comparison of inhibitors identified in different assays challenging. The α-OH substituted compound showed an IC50 of 235 μM in the allopregnanolone assay and 610 μM in the estradiol assay.(123) Further modification (9) resulted in 58.8% inhibition of ABAD activity at 300 μM in the estradiol assay. However, in the allopregnanolone assay at 100 μM concentration, 9 showed only 8% inhibition of ABAD activity.

    Frentizole Analogues

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Frentizole, an FDA approved immunosuppressant drug, was identified as an Aβ–ABAD interaction inhibitor (IC50 = 200 μM) using an ELISA-based screening assay.(94) Structure–activity relationship studies performed on the benzothiazole moiety, encompassing a library of 45 analogues, identified the urea moiety as pharmacophoric. The benzothiazole ring SAR identified that a halogen electron-withdrawing group (EWG), such as chlorine (10) or fluorine (11), enhances activity. Exploration of the SAR of the terminal phenyl ring revealed appendage of functionality with increased polarity around all substituent positions enhanced ABAD inhibition activity. Further increase in activity was achieved with a para-substituted hydroxy group, with further enhancement of activity achieved when a methyl ester was introduced ortho to the hydroxy. Two active benzothiazole-based inhibitors, compounds 10 and 11, were identified to inhibit Aβ–ABAD interaction with IC50 values of 6.46 μM and 6.56 μM, respectively, when halogen, para-hydroxy, and methyl ester functionalities were combined.(94) However, the activity of these compounds to inhibit Aβ-induced cytotoxicity in vitro or in vivo has not been determined. Further SAR studies for the benzothiazoleurea phenyl scaffold retained the para-hydroxy group and included an ortho-chlorine on the terminal phenyl ring combined with an EWG group on the benzothiazole ring.(128) Compound 12 at 25 μM concentration resulted in 80% inhibition of ABAD activity in which acetoacetyl-CoA was used as a substrate in the assay. Another compound with the benzothiazoleurea phenyl backbone (15) bearing a 3,5-dichloro-4-hydroxyphenyl scaffold showed similar ABAD inhibition activity to compound 12.(128) Interestingly, compounds 10 and 11, when tested in the assay used to identify 15, showed almost no inhibition activity at 25 μM concentration (4% and 3% inhibition, respectively) despite being the most potent inhibitors in the Aβ–ABAD interaction assay. This again makes the direct comparison of inhibitors identified in different assays challenging.
    In the search for dual-acting molecules that can inhibit mitochondrial-induced toxicity by acting on two distinct pathological processes, another study developed inhibitors of casein kinase 1 (CK1) activity that were also capable of inhibiting ABAD. Isoforms of CK1 are responsible for tau phosphorylation.(129) The enzyme can modulate the activity of γ-secretase and consequently the production of Aβ.(130) Screening previously synthesized frentizole derivatives for their efficiency to inhibit CK1 activity as well as ABAD identified compound 13 which possessed an ABAD IC50 = 1.67 μM, the most potent inhibitor of this chemotype identified to date.(74) The compound combines the pharmacophoric features of the benzothiazole urea derivatives, a chlorine substituted benzothiazole ring, the urea linker, and a para-hydroxy moiety on the terminal phenyl ring, with an adjacent chlorine. Direct substitution of the chlorine of 13 with a more electron-withdrawing fluorine atom (14) resulted in similar activity with ABAD IC50 = 1.89 μM.
    In summary, the presence of the hydroxy group attached to the para position of the phenylurea ring is shown to be essential for its ability to inhibit ABAD and the addition of an adjacent EWG (such as chlorine or an ester) greatly increases this activity. These modifications are combined with the pharmacophoric role of an EWG on the benzothiazole ring.

    Benzothiazole Linker Analogues

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Further studies on the frentizole chemotype aimed at changes in the linker moiety identified a benzothiazoleamino phosphonate analogue that possessed moderate affinity for binding ABAD. Conversion of the benzothiazole urea linker to a benzothiazole aminomethyl phosphonate linker (16) results in reduced inhibition activity (IC50 = 52.7 μM) but a somewhat improved pharmacokinetic profile.(131) Analyzing the SAR of this inhibitor showed similar results to the initial SAR performed on the parent.(94) As anticipated, a hydroxy group on the terminal phenyl ring at the para-position is essential for ABAD inhibition.(131) In vitro studies of compound 16 showed a reduction in calcium-induced mPTP, decreased Aβ-induced mitochondrial dysfunction, and increased ATP levels.(132) Blood–brain barrier (BBB) permeability is obviously crucial for a CNS drug.(133) Compound 16 achieved somewhat limited penetration, yielding 4–50 ng/mL peak brain concentration and 2 μg/mL peak plasma concentration from a 10 mg/kg dose in male and female C57BL/6 mice.(134) However, the achieved Cmax in the brain (4.8 ng/mL) from a 10 mg/kg dose prohibits the exposure of an IC50 amount of compound. Thus, therapeutically effective target engagement would not be possible. The scaffold serves as a novel chemotype for inhibiting ABAD that requires further optimization to achieve submicromolar inhibition activity and BBB penetration. However, the BBB penetration of this scaffold may be an unsurmountable roadblock. The limited chemical space available around the aminophosphonate moiety and the limitations imposed by the known pharmacophore may prohibit coexistence of both potent activity and BBB penetration. These results spurred the investigation of modified-linker analogues to adjust the pharmacophoric features of the parent compound by substituting the urea linker with guanidine or the addition of a methoxy group at the para-position of the phenylurea. This library identified compound 17, possessing ABAD IC50 = 3.06 μM. The compound showed satisfactory physicochemical properties, presenting a novel lead structure for inhibition of the Aβ–ABAD interaction that may penetrate the BBB.(135)

    Combination ABAD/MAOI Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The frentizole scaffold has been combined with the known monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) ladostigil to identify a molecule that has a dual effect: inhibiting both ABAD and MAO. A library of synthesized derivatives demonstrated that the most potent inhibitor for MAO (IC50 = 6.34 μM) lacked ABAD inhibition activity. However, the study did identify that a moderately potent ABAD inhibitor, compound 18, at 100 μM concentration possessed approximately 60% inhibition of ABAD activity.(136)

    Targeting Loop D

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The recently obtained X-ray structure of human ABAD in complex with the Aβ protein strongly substantiated the conjecture that Aβ binding to ABAD distorts the native conformation and normal function of the enzyme.(137) However, poor election density prevents the visualization of Aβ in crystal form. The region of ABAD comprising amino acid residues 95–113, termed loop D (LD), becomes highly disordered following Aβ binding. Thus, the LD area of ABAD was subjected to docking studies to identify potential inhibitors. Receptor-based pharmacophore modeling, as well as a virtual screening of the Asinex and Chemdiv chemical databases, identified 20 hits, two of which, compounds 19 and 20, possessed ABAD inhibition activity, with IC50 values of 4.4 and 9.6 μM, respectively. These compounds were evaluated for their ability to ameliorate Aβ-induced mitochondrial dysfunction in HT-22 cells, resulting in reduction of cell toxicity and Aβ-induced ATP depletion.(137)

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this review we have cemented the Aβ–ABAD interaction as a crucial modulator of the magnitude of Aβ-induced neurotoxicity. Inhibition of this interaction may provide candidate therapeutics for AD that can conceivably act in a disease-modifying manner. Medicinal chemistry to engage this novel target is in its infancy as only moderately potent inhibitors (IC50 values of 53–1.5 μM) have yet been identified, most of which occupy only limited chemical space, with the frentizole chemotype dominating. Only one chemotype (1) possesses submicromolar activity to date, and this has resulted in just seven compounds with such activity. Continued development of pharmacophore mapping and extensive structure–activity relationship studies being conducted in our laboratory and others are anticipated to provide access to potent and “drug-like” ABAD inhibitors. Such compounds will be employed for lead discovery and as chemical probes to identify the significance of inhibiting the Aβ–ABAD protein–protein interaction on the integrity of the cell in terms of protein expression, mitochondrial function, and cell viability.

    1. 1
      Albert, M. S.; DeKosky, S. T.; Dickson, D.; Dubois, B.; Feldman, H. H.; Fox, N. C.; Gamst, A.; Holtzman, D. M.; Jagust, W. J.; Petersen, R. C.; Snyder, P. J.; Carrillo, M. C.; Thies, B.; Phelps, C. H. The diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment due to Alzheimer’s disease: recommendations from the national institute on aging-Alzheimer’s association workgroups on diagnostic guidelines for Alzheimer’s disease. Alzheimer's Dementia 2011, 7, 270– 279,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jalz.2011.03.008
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      The diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment due to Alzheimer's disease: recommendations from the National Institute on Aging-Alzheimer's Association workgroups on diagnostic guidelines for Alzheimer's disease
      Albert Marilyn S; DeKosky Steven T; Dickson Dennis; Dubois Bruno; Feldman Howard H; Fox Nick C; Gamst Anthony; Holtzman David M; Jagust William J; Petersen Ronald C; Snyder Peter J; Carrillo Maria C; Thies Bill; Phelps Creighton H
      Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association (2011), 7 (3), 270-9 ISSN:.
      The National Institute on Aging and the Alzheimer's Association charged a workgroup with the task of developing criteria for the symptomatic predementia phase of Alzheimer's disease (AD), referred to in this article as mild cognitive impairment due to AD. The workgroup developed the following two sets of criteria: (1) core clinical criteria that could be used by healthcare providers without access to advanced imaging techniques or cerebrospinal fluid analysis, and (2) research criteria that could be used in clinical research settings, including clinical trials. The second set of criteria incorporate the use of biomarkers based on imaging and cerebrospinal fluid measures. The final set of criteria for mild cognitive impairment due to AD has four levels of certainty, depending on the presence and nature of the biomarker findings. Considerable work is needed to validate the criteria that use biomarkers and to standardize biomarker analysis for use in community settings.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3MrhsFaktA%253D%253D&md5=609df181936d75a42ae8db4826713f85
    2. 2
      Price, D. L.; Sisodia, S. S. Mutant genes in familial Alzheimer’s disease and transgenic models. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1998, 21, 479– 505,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev.neuro.21.1.479
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Mutant genes in familial Alzheimer's disease and transgenic models
      Price, Donald L.; Sisodia, Sangram S.
      Annual Review of Neuroscience (1998), 21 (), 479-505CODEN: ARNSD5; ISSN:0147-006X. (Annual Reviews Inc.)
      A review, with 163 refs. The most common cause of dementia occurring in mid- to late-life is Alzheimer's disease (AD). Some cases of AD, particularly those of early onset, are familial and inherited as autosomal dominant disorders linked to the presence of mutant genes that encode the amyloid precursor protein (APP) or the presenilins (PS1 or PS2). These mutant gene products cause dysfunction/death of vulnerable populations of nerve cells important in memory, higher cognitive processes, and behavior. AD affects 7-10% of individuals >65 yr of age and perhaps 40% of individuals >80 yr of age. For the late-onset cases, the principal risk factors are age and apolipoprotein (apoE) allele type, with apoE4 allele being a susceptibility factor. In this review, we briefly discuss the clin. syndrome of AD and the neurobiol./neuropathol. of the disease and then focus attention on mutant genes linked to autosomal dominant familial AD (FAD), the biol. of the proteins encoded by these genes, and the recent exciting progress in investigations of genetically engineered animal models that express these mutant genes and develop some features of AD.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXhsFyhtLY%253D&md5=fa1bf9dbad95faabcd6854eca46bad83
    3. 3
      Selkoe, D. J. Translating cell biology into therapeutic advances in Alzheimer’s disease. Nature 1999, 399, A23– A31,  DOI: 10.1038/399a023
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Translating cell biology into therapeutic advances in Alzheimer's disease
      Selkoe, Dennis J.
      Nature (London) (1999), 399 (6738, Suppl.), A23-A31CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
      A review, with 100 refs. Studies of the mol. basis of Alzheimer's disease exemplify the increasingly blurred distinction between basic and applied biomedical research. The four genes so far implicated in familial Alzheimer's disease have each been shown to elevate brain levels of the self-aggregating amyloid-β protein, leading gradually to profound neuronal and glial alteration, synaptic loss, and dementia. Progress in understanding this cascade has helped to identify specific therapeutic targets and provides a model for elucidating other neurodegenerative disorders.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXktlejsLg%253D&md5=617535c8a17e13091e330acb6bfcf8b2
    4. 4
      Selkoe, D. J.; Hardy, J. The amyloid hypothesis of Alzheimer’s disease at 25 years. EMBO Mol. Med. 2016, 8, 595– 608,  DOI: 10.15252/emmm.201606210
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      The amyloid hypothesis of Alzheimer's disease at 25 years
      Selkoe, Dennis J.; Hardy, John
      EMBO Molecular Medicine (2016), 8 (6), 595-608CODEN: EMMMAM; ISSN:1757-4684. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      Despite continuing debate about the amyloid β-protein or Aβ hypothesis, new lines of evidence from labs. and clinics worldwide support the concept that an imbalance between prodn. and clearance of Aβ42 and related Aβ peptides is a very early, often initiating factor in Alzheimer's disease AD. Confirmation that presenilin is the catalytic site of γ-secretase has provided a linchpin: all dominant mutations causing early-onset AD occur either in the substrate amyloid precursor protein, APP or the protease presenilin of the reaction that generates Aβ. Duplication of the wild-type APP gene in Down's syndrome leads to Aβ deposits in the teens, followed by microgliosis, astrocytosis, and neurofibrillary tangles typical of AD. Apolipoprotein E4, which predisposes to AD in > 40% of cases, has been found to impair Aβ clearance from the brain. Sol. oligomers of Aβ42 isolated from AD patients' brains can decrease synapse no., inhibit long-term potentiation, and enhance long-term synaptic depression in rodent hippocampus, and injecting them into healthy rats impairs memory. The human oligomers also induce hyperphosphorylation of tau at AD-relevant epitopes and cause neuritic dystrophy in cultured neurons. Crossing human APP with human tau transgenic mice enhances tau-pos. neurotoxicity. In humans, new studies show that low cerebrospinal fluid CSF Aβ42 and amyloid-PET positivity precede other AD manifestations by many years. Most importantly, recent trials of three different Aβ antibodies solanezumab, crenezumab, and aducanumab have suggested a slowing of cognitive decline in post hoc analyses of mild AD subjects. Although many factors contribute to AD pathogenesis, Aβ dyshomeostasis has emerged as the most extensively validated and compelling therapeutic target.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XltVOhtL8%253D&md5=b7a2003ba5d341f5eef5c7e9454235ce
    5. 5
      Selkoe, D. J.; Schenk, D. Alzheimer’s disease: molecular understanding predicts amyloid-based therapeutics. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2003, 43, 545– 584,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev.pharmtox.43.100901.140248
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Alzheimer's disease: Molecular understanding predicts amyloid-based therapeutics
      Selkoe, Dennis J.; Schenk, Dale
      Annual Review of Pharmacology and Toxicology (2003), 43 (), 545-584CODEN: ARPTDI; ISSN:0362-1642. (Annual Reviews Inc.)
      A review. Degenerative diseases of the brain were long considered among the most obscure and intractable of human maladies. However, recent advances in understanding their mechanisms have brought us to the verge of potential disease-modifying agents. This progress is perhaps best exemplified by the case of Alzheimer's disease. The application of mol. pathol. and genetics has led to the recognition that the 4 genes implicated to date in familial Alzheimer's disease all chronically elevate cerebral levels of the amyloid β-protein (Aβ). Accordingly, small mol. inhibitors of the β- and γ-secretases, the proteases that generate Aβ from its precursor, are under active development, and some have shown in vivo efficacy in mouse models. An alternative approach, active or passive immunization against Aβ, has received extensive pre-clin. validation in mice, but an effective prepn. free of significant side effects in humans is still awaited. Several other potential therapies are also reviewed here. If one or more of these varied approaches is ultimately proven to slow or prevent dementia, Alzheimer's disease will become a salient example of the successful application of reductionist biol. to the most complex of organs, the human cerebral cortex.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXitFWqt74%253D&md5=5298d8939885e0b94bf43472721f0455
    6. 6
      Cummings, J. Lessons learned from Alzheimer disease: clinical trials with negative outcomes. Clin. Transl. Sci. 2018, 11, 147– 152,  DOI: 10.1111/cts.12491
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Cummings Jeffrey
      Clinical and translational science (2018), 11 (2), 147-152 ISSN:.

      Mehta, D.; Jackson, R.; Paul, G.; Shi, J.; Sabbagh, M. Why do trials for Alzheimer’s disease drugs keep failing? a discontinued drug perspective for 2010–2015. Expert Opin. Invest. Drugs 2017, 26, 735– 739,  DOI: 10.1080/13543784.2017.1323868
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Why do trials for Alzheimer's disease drugs keep failing? A discontinued drug perspective for 2010-2015
      Mehta, Dev; Jackson, Robert; Paul, Gaurav; Shi, Jiong; Sabbagh, Marwan
      Expert Opinion on Investigational Drugs (2017), 26 (6), 735-739CODEN: EOIDER; ISSN:1354-3784. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
      : There are dozens of drugs in development for AD with billions of dollars invested. Despite the massive investment in AD drugs and a burgeoning pipeline, there have been more setbacks and failures than treatment successes.: The classes of drugs that have failed to date include the monoclonal antibodies, the gamma secretase inhibitors, dimebon, neurochem. enhancers, and one tau drug. Data for these compds. were sought through a PubMed search and a clin. trials.gov search.: The obvious question to be posed is: Why are they failing. Is the treatment of symptomatic dementia too late. Are the therapeutic targets incorrect. Are the clin. methodologies imprecise, misleading, or inaccurate. This review summarizes the drugs that have failed during 2010-2015 and offers possible theories as to why they have failed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXot1Shu7Y%253D&md5=efa88fffd86b5674b1b3f19342947933
    8. 8
      Small, D. H.; McLean, C. A. Alzheimer’s disease and the amyloid β protein: what is the role of amyloid?. J. Neurochem. 1999, 73, 443– 449,  DOI: 10.1046/j.1471-4159.1999.0730443.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Alzheimer's disease and the amyloid β protein: what is the role of amyloid?
      Small, David H.; McLean, Catriona A.
      Journal of Neurochemistry (1999), 73 (2), 443-449CODEN: JONRA9; ISSN:0022-3042. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      A review with 96 refs. Topics include: amyloid protein and amyloid precursor protein; role of amyloid β in Alzheimer's disease pathogenesis; amyloid precursor protein transgenic mice; amyloid toxicity in vitro; apolipoprotein E and amyloid β toxicity; is sol. amyloid β important in Alzheimer's pathogenesis; a novel variant of Alzheimer's disease; is amyloid β1-42/43 the only toxic form of amyloid β.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXkslOqsr4%253D&md5=af8c07e499b2f64f4d0a38d35afce700
    9. 9
      Cleary, J. P.; Walsh, D. M.; Hofmeister, J. J.; Shankar, G. M.; Kuskowski, M. A.; Selkoe, D. J.; Ashe, K. H. Natural oligomers of the amyloid-β protein specifically disrupt cognitive function. Nat. Neurosci. 2005, 8, 79– 84,  DOI: 10.1038/nn1372
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Natural oligomers of the amyloid-beta protein specifically disrupt cognitive function
      Cleary James P; Walsh Dominic M; Hofmeister Jacki J; Shankar Ganesh M; Kuskowski Michael A; Selkoe Dennis J; Ashe Karen H
      Nature neuroscience (2005), 8 (1), 79-84 ISSN:1097-6256.
      A central unresolved problem in research on Alzheimer disease is the nature of the molecular entity causing dementia. Here we provide the first direct experimental evidence that a defined molecular species of the amyloid-beta protein interferes with cognitive function. Soluble oligomeric forms of amyloid-beta, including trimers and dimers, were both necessary and sufficient to disrupt learned behavior in a manner that was rapid, potent and transient; they produced impaired cognitive function without inducing permanent neurological deficits. Although beta-amyloidosis has long been hypothesized to affect cognition, the abnormally folded protein species associated with this or any other neurodegenerative disease has not previously been isolated, defined biochemically and then specifically characterized with regard to its effects on cognitive function. The biochemical isolation of discrete amyloid-beta moieties with pathophysiological properties sets the stage for a new approach to studying the molecular mechanisms of cognitive impairment in Alzheimer disease and related neurodegenerative disorders.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2cnksFeqsQ%253D%253D&md5=538ad375375c965463e33ae791da930d
    10. 10
      Manczak, M.; Anekonda, T. S.; Henson, E.; Park, B. S.; Quinn, J.; Reddy, P. H. Mitochondria are a direct site of Aβ accumulation in Alzheimer’s disease neurons: implications for free radical generation and oxidative damage in disease progression. Hum. Mol. Genet. 2006, 15, 1437– 1449,  DOI: 10.1093/hmg/ddl066
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Mitochondria are a direct site of Aβ accumulation in Alzheimer's disease neurons: implications for free radical generation and oxidative damage in disease progression
      Manczak, Maria; Anekonda, Thimmappa S.; Henson, Edward; Park, Byung S.; Quinn, Joseph; Reddy, P. Hemachandra
      Human Molecular Genetics (2006), 15 (9), 1437-1449CODEN: HMGEE5; ISSN:0964-6906. (Oxford University Press)
      Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a complex, neurodegenerative disease characterized by the impairment of cognitive function in elderly individuals. In a recent global gene expression study of APP transgenic mice, we found elevated expression of mitochondrial genes, which we hypothesize represents a compensatory response because of mitochondrial oxidative damage caused by the over-expression of mutant APP and/or amyloid beta (Aβ). We investigated this hypothesis in a series of expts. examg. what forms of APP and Aβ localize to the mitochondria, and whether the presence of these species is assocd. with mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative damage. Using immunoblotting, digitonin fractionation, immunofluorescence, and electron microscopy techniques, we found a relationship between mutant APP derivs. and mitochondria in brain slices from Tg2576 mice and in mouse neuroblastoma cells expressing mutant human APP. Further, to det. the functional relationship between mutant APP/Aβ and oxidative damage, we quantified Aβ levels, hydrogen peroxide prodn., cytochrome oxidase activity and carbonyl proteins in Tg2576 mice and age-matched wild-type (WT) littermates. Hydrogen peroxide levels were found to be significantly increased in Tg2576 mice when compared with age-matched WT littermates and directly correlated with levels of sol. Aβ in Tg2576 mice, suggesting that sol. Aβ may be responsible for the prodn. of hydrogen peroxide in AD progression in Tg2576 mice. Cytochrome c oxidase activity was found to be decreased in Tg2576 mice when compared with age-matched WT littermates, suggesting that mutant APP and sol. Aβ impair mitochondrial metab. in AD development and progression. An increase in hydrogen peroxide and a decrease in cytochrome oxidase activity were found in young Tg2576 mice, prior to the appearance of Aβ plaques. These findings suggest that early mitochondrially targeted therapeutic interventions may be effective in delaying AD progression in elderly individuals and in treating AD patients.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjslGhsLs%253D&md5=c2f689e07c3b0b7950d1758684c263f7
    11. 11
      Reddy, P. H.; Mani, G.; Park, B. S.; Jacques, J.; Murdoch, G.; Whetsell, Jr.; Kaye, J.; Manczak, M. Differential loss of synaptic proteins in Alzheimer’s disease: implications for synaptic dysfunction. J. Alzheimer's Dis. 2005, 7, 103– 117,  DOI: 10.3233/JAD-2005-7203
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Differential loss of synaptic proteins in Alzheimer's disease: Implications for synaptic dysfunction
      Reddy, P. Hemachandra; Mani, Geethalakshmi; Park, Byung S.; Jacques, Joline; Murdoch, Geoffrey; Whetsell, William, Jr.; Kaye, Jeffrey; Manczak, Maria
      Journal of Alzheimer's Disease (2005), 7 (2), 103-117CODEN: JADIF9; ISSN:1387-2877. (IOS Press)
      The objective of our research was to det. synaptic protein levels in brain specimens from AD subjects and age-matched control subjects. Further, to det. whether presynaptic or postsynaptic compartments of neurons are preferentially affected in AD patients, we studied 3 presynaptic vesicle proteins (synaptotagmin, synaptophysin, and Rab 3A), 2 synaptic membrane proteins (Gap 43 and synaptobrevin), and 2 postsynaptic proteins (neurogranin and synaptopodin) in specimens from AD and age-matched control brains. Two brain regions - the frontal and parietal cortices - were assessed for protein levels by immunoblotting anal. We found a loss of both presynaptic vesicle proteins and postsynaptic proteins in all brain specimens from AD patients compared to those from age-matched control subjects. Further, we found that the loss of synaptic proteins was more severe in the frontal cortex brain specimens than in the parietal cortex brain specimens from the AD subjects compared to those from the control subjects, suggesting that the frontal brain may be crit. for synaptic function in AD. Using immunohistochem. techniques, we also detd. the distribution pattern of all synaptic proteins in both the frontal and parietal cortices brain specimens from control subjects. Of the 7 synaptic proteins studied, the presynaptic proteins synaptophysin and rab 3A and the postsynaptic protein synaptopodin were the most down-regulated. Our study suggests that postsynaptic proteins and presynaptic proteins are important for synaptic function and may be related to cognitive impairments in AD.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjsVSjs70%253D&md5=5de577ab06fd74e163f4f264d11a9843
    12. 12
      Reddy, P. H.; McWeeney, S.; Park, B. S.; Manczak, M.; Gutala, R. V.; Partovi, D.; Jung, Y.; Yau, V.; Searles, R.; Mori, M.; Quinn, J. Gene expression profiles of transcripts in amyloid precursor protein transgenic mice: up-regulation of mitochondrial metabolism and apoptotic genes is an early cellular change in Alzheimer’s disease. Hum. Mol. Genet. 2004, 13, 1225– 1240,  DOI: 10.1093/hmg/ddh140
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Gene expression profiles of transcripts in amyloid precursor protein transgenic mice: up-regulation of mitochondrial metabolism and apoptotic genes is an early cellular change in Alzheimer's disease
      Reddy, P. Hemachandra; McWeeney, Shannon; Park, Byung S.; Manczak, Maria; Gutala, Ramana V.; Partovi, Dara; Jung, Youngsin; Yau, Vincent; Searles, Robert; Mori, Motomi; Quinn, Joseph
      Human Molecular Genetics (2004), 13 (12), 1225-1240CODEN: HMGEE5; ISSN:0964-6906. (Oxford University Press)
      Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease characterized by the impairment of cognitive functions and by beta amyloid (Aβ) plaques in the cerebral cortex and the hippocampus. Our objective was to det. genes that are crit. for cellular changes in AD progression, with particular emphasis on changes early in disease progression. We investigated an established amyloid precursor protein (APP) transgenic mouse model (the Tg2576 mouse model) for gene expression profiles at three stages of disease progression: long before (2 mo of age), immediately before (5 mo) and after (18 mo) the appearance of Aβ plaques. Using cDNA microarray techniques, we measured mRNA levels in 11 283 cDNA clones from the cerebral cortex of Tg2576 mice and age-matched wild-type (WT) mice at each of the three time points. This gene expression anal. revealed that the genes related to mitochondrial energy metab. and apoptosis were up-regulated in 2-mo-old Tg2576 mice and that the same genes were up-regulated at 5 and 18 mo of age. These microarray results were confirmed using northern blot anal. Results from in situ hybridization of mitochondrial genes-ATPase-6, heat-shock protein 86 and programmed cell death gene 8-suggest that the granule cells of the hippocampal dentate gyrus and the pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus and the cerebral cortex are up-regulated in Tg2576 mice compared with WT mice. Results from double-labeling in situ hybridization suggest that in Tg2576 mice only selective, over-expressed neurons with the mitochondrial gene ATPase-6 undergo oxidative damage. These results, therefore, suggest that mitochondrial energy metab. is impaired by the expression of mutant APP and/or Aβ, and that the up-regulation of mitochondrial genes is a compensatory response. These findings have important implications for understanding the mechanism of Aβ toxicity in AD and for developing therapeutic strategies for AD.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXktF2qtLg%253D&md5=4ab7f2b86af2799003dda9676ff64dac
    13. 13
      Reddy, P. H.; Beal, M. F. Are mitochondria critical in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease?. Brain Res. Rev. 2005, 49, 618– 632,  DOI: 10.1016/j.brainresrev.2005.03.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Are mitochondria critical in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease?
      Reddy, P. Hemachandra; Beal, M. Flint
      Brain Research Reviews (2005), 49 (3), 618-632CODEN: BRERD2; ISSN:0165-0173. (Elsevier B.V.)
      This review summarizes recent findings that suggest a causal connection between mitochondrial abnormalities and sporadic Alzheimer's disease (AD). Genetic causes of AD are known only for a small proportion of familial AD patients, but for a majority of sporadic AD patients, genetic causal factors are still unknown. Currently, there are no early detectable biomarkers for sporadic AD, and there is a lack of understanding of the pathophysiol. of the disease. Findings from recent genetic studies of AD pathogenesis suggest that mitochondrial defects may play an important role in sporadic AD progression, and that mitochondrial abnormalities and oxidative damage may play a significant role in the progression of familial AD. Findings from biochem. studies, in vitro studies, gene expression studies, and animal model studies of AD are reviewed, and the possible contribution of mitochondrial mutations to late-onset sporadic AD is discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtFOhsbrL&md5=eb375220b5f5eccb90b2b119f97f3377
    14. 14
      Trippier, P. C.; Jansen Labby, K.; Hawker, D. D.; Mataka, J. J.; Silverman, R. B. Target- and mechanism-based therapeutics for neurodegenerative diseases: strength in numbers. J. Med. Chem. 2013, 56, 3121– 3147,  DOI: 10.1021/jm3015926
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      Target- and Mechanism-Based Therapeutics for Neurodegenerative Diseases: Strength in Numbers
      Trippier, Paul C.; Jansen Labby, Kristin; Hawker, Dustin D.; Mataka, Jan J.; Silverman, Richard B.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2013), 56 (8), 3121-3147CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The development of new therapeutics for the treatment of neurodegenerative pathophysiologies currently stands at a crossroads. This presents an opportunity to transition future drug discovery efforts to target disease modification, an area in which much still remains unknown. In this Perspective we examine recent progress in the areas of neurodegenerative drug discovery, focusing on some of the most common targets and mechanisms: N-methyl-d-aspartic acid (NMDA) receptors, voltage gated calcium channels (VGCCs), neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS), oxidative stress from reactive oxygen species, and protein aggregation. These represent the key players identified in neurodegeneration and are part of a complex, intertwined signaling cascade. The synergistic delivery of two or more compds. directed against these targets, along with the design of small mols. with multiple modes of action, should be explored in pursuit of more effective clin. treatments for neurodegenerative diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjsFeju78%253D&md5=a8ea6d8cf4f9d3bba76d40ceacc9c26d
